conclusion: Analyzing whether the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds using the v-t graph.
Variable linear motion means the velocity is changing, which appears as a non-horizontal line on a v-t graph.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s: The velocity is constant at v = 2 m/s (horizontal line).
From t = 1 to t = 2 s: The velocity decreases linearly from v = 2 m/s to v = 0 m/s (sloped line).
From t = 2 to t = 3 s: The velocity continues decreasing linearly from v = 0 m/s to v = -2 m/s (sloped line).
In the interval t = 0 to t = 1 s: No change in velocity (constant).
In the interval t = 1 to t = 2 s: Velocity is changing (decreasing).
In the interval t = 2 to t = 3 s: Velocity is changing (decreasing).
t = 0 to t = 1 s: a = 0 (no acceleration).
t = 1 to t = 2 s: a = -2 m/s² (negative acceleration/deceleration).
t = 2 to t = 3 s: a = -2 m/s² (negative acceleration).
Yes, the particle did undergo variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
